Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch dev into main (NuGet.Jobs and ServerCommon merge)" (#10135) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This brings the NuGet.Jobs and ServerCommon source trees into `main` branch. They have already been merged into `dev` branch as of https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10091 and https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10109.

That's a lot of content to review, so let's focus on the changes NOT including NuGet.Jobs and ServerCommon. I have listed them here with diff links to illustrate how I found them:

- Changes between the NuGet.Jobs merge and the ServerCommon merge: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/compare/d55ed52c78a34c5416ecd6734af8e1aad0d97765...a782405fbacf8ac657caec334aae115273a95d02
  - @clairernovotny
    - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10083
  - @martinrrm
    - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10096
  - @erdembayar
    - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10098
  - @joelverhagen - many (I have verified the changes I want to deploy)
- Changes between ServerCommon merge and latest `dev`: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/compare/968432180cad66123c6541ba89b562e0cbb22a8d...ef1455c0a31dd97623f14a817f5bcab80e39efb0
   - @Goodyear2017
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10103
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10105
  - @clairernovotny
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10107
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10114
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10122
      - https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/10134
  - @joelverhagen - many (I have verified the changes I want to deploy)

In other words, these are the changes made to NuGetGallery or post-merge NuGet.Jobs and ServerCommon states.

DEV environment has latest `dev` branch deployment so you should be able to verify your changes there right now if you are worries:
https://dev.nugettest.org/

The rollout plan is to deploy the following jobs and services:
- NuGetGallery (web app)
   - @martinrrm, @clairernovotny, and @Goodyear2017 are to verify their changes in INT then PROD.
   - Purpose: dark mode fixes, V2 download URL change, accessibility fixes
- MonitoringProcessor
   - @joelverhagen is to verify his changes in INT then PROD.
   - Purpose: auth for Azure Search cursors
- Catalog2Monitoring
   - @joelverhagen is to verify his changes in INT then PROD.
   - Purpose: auth for Azure Search cursors

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Use auth for downloads.v1.json in stats and search jobs" (#10137) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/5576.

This changes `DownloadsV1JsonClient` to use `BlobClient` instead of `HttpClient`. The initialized blob client (`BlobClient`) in this case is meant to be a singleton so I inverted the control so the downloads.v1.json is provided via DI. This works because we really only have one downloads.v1.json URL at a time, coming from config. It doesn't need to be a parameter.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Getting too similar name upload error for packages that I own" (#10133) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

I own a [series of packages][github] on nuget.org that match up with .NET target framework monikers. 

- Basic.Reference.Assemblies.Net461
- Basic.Reference.Assemblies.Net60
- Basic.Reference.Assemblies.Net70
- Basic.Reference.Assemblies.Net80
- Basic.Reference.Assemblies.NetStandard20

This morning was attempting to release a new package Basic.Reference.Assemblies.Net20. When my action attempted to publish I got the following error:

> The uploaded package's id is too similar to the already existing packages:

I doubled checked that I don't have any weird authoring mistakes on my new package (verified in package explorer that it has the ID I was expecting). Yes the difference between existing names is only one character but I already have several versions of the package which have that characteristic. 

Tried uploading manually through the gallery and got the same error. When displayed in the gallery though it feels like the error is truncated. The trailing colon makes me think it should be displaying the similar names (maybe I'm off here). 

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/30b65a49-0376-4489-a8c2-88e00508f89c)

At this point though I'm blocked from moving forward on some work in github.com/dotnet/roslyn because we can't upload these new packages for TFMs we want to test. 

[github]: https://github.com/jaredpar/basic-reference-assemblies

### Repro Steps

Have to build the package from https://github.com/jaredpar/basic-reference-assemblies and then attempt to upload and it you will see the error. 

### Expected Behavior

I should be able to upload the new package. Yes it is similar to existing names but I'm the package owner for all those packages with similar names. 

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add client name translation" (#10134) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This pull request includes significant updates to the `loginterpretation` module, primarily focusing on adding new functionality for client name translation using dataclasses and enhancing test coverage. The most important changes include the introduction of dataclasses for client categories and names, the implementation of client name translation logic, and the addition of unit tests to validate the new functionality.

### Enhancements to Client Name Translation:

* [`python/StatsLogParser/loginterpretation/clientnametranslation.py`](diffhunk://#diff-06e97ee9e63716b28eb1e56eddb92fc1661357638c30fd5c3abacfee8bcdadb2R1-R153): Introduced `ClientCategories` and `ClientNames` dataclasses to categorize client names and implemented the `ClientNameTranslation` class with static methods for client name translation logic.

### Version Update:

* [`python/StatsLogParser/pyproject.toml`](diffhunk://#diff-ff4027217dcdbffd156d66cb6e7eb2410e07db7cb4d8c9f10614c616b16e9b71L3-R3): Updated the version of the `loginterpretation` module from `0.1.0` to `0.2.0`.

### Test Coverage:

* [`python/StatsLogParser/tests/test_clientnametranslation.py`](diffhunk://#diff-b82052d01739ad76a6781ec8a701ebfb5746dd97e46f873189744153cc4f5a02R1-R24): Added unit tests using `pytest` to validate the `ClientNameTranslation` logic, ensuring correct categorization of client names.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c0f94518-00d2-42cc-94bb-adbf7d5b9c67)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "<vulnerabilityDataSource> in Nuget.config not working if Nuget.org is added as a disabled package source" (#13716) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

9.0.100-preview.7.24407.12

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

I want to use Nuget.org just as a vulnerability source, not as a package source. So, my existing Nuget.config had these lines added in it:

```
<disabledPackageSources>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="Microsoft Azure Service Fabric" value="true" />
    <add key="Microsoft and .NET" value="true" />
</disabledPackageSources>
```

According to this comment: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12698#issuecomment-1606988777, adding this should have allowed me to use Nuget.org as a  vulnerability source but I have been unable to get it to work.

```
<vulnerabilityDataSource>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
  <vulnerabilityDataSource>
```


I have tried this with .NET SDK 8.0.300, 8.0.400 and 9.0.100-preview.7.24407.12, didn't work with any of these. Infact, I observed that adding `<vulnerabilityDataSource>` in my Nuget.config didnt make any difference at all.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Run `cd C:\MyTest`.
2) Run `dotnet new classlib --framework "netstandard2.0" -o MyTest`.
3) Open the .csproj in Visual Studio and add a package reference to System.Formats.Asn1 6.0.0 which has a known high security vulnerability.
After this my .csproj looks like this:

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="System.Formats.Asn1" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```
4) Create a global.json file in C:\MyTest to make use of .NET SDK 9.0.100-preview.7.24407.12 (or .NET SDK 8.0.300 or .NET SDK 8.0.401) with these contents:

```
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "9.0.100-preview.7.24407.12",
    "rollForward": "latestFeature"
  }
}
```
5) Create a NuGet.config in C:\MyTest with these contents:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageRestore>
    <add key="enabled" value="True" />
    <add key="automatic" value="True" />
  </packageRestore>
  <packageSources>
	  <add key="RETRACTED 1" value="A VALID V2 URL" />
	  <add key="RETRACTED 2" value="ANOTHER VALID V2 URL" />
  </packageSources>
  <vulnerabilityDataSource>
    <add key="NuGet Vulnerability DB" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
  </vulnerabilityDataSource>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="Microsoft Azure Service Fabric" value="true" />
    <add key="Microsoft and .NET" value="true" />
</disabledPackageSources>
  <activePackageSource>
	  <add key="RETRACTED 1" value="A VALID V2 URL" />
	  <add key="RETRACTED 2" value="ANOTHER VALID V2 URL" />
  </activePackageSource>
</configuration>

```

6) Run `dotnet nuget config get ALL` to get the combined Nuget.config created form all Nuget.config, this is the output I get:

```
C:\MyTest\MyTest>dotnet nuget config get ALL
packageSources:
        add key="RETRACTED 1" value="A VALID V2 URL"
        add key="RETRACTED 2" value="ANOTHER V2 URL"
        add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" protocolVersion="3"
        add key="Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages" value="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\"

fallbackPackageFolders:
        add key="Microsoft Visual Studio Fallback Folder" value="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\Shared\NuGetPackages"

packageRestore:
        add key="enabled" value="True"
        add key="automatic" value="True"

vulnerabilityDataSource:
        add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json"

disabledPackageSources:
        add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json"
        add key="Microsoft Azure Service Fabric" value="true"
        add key="Microsoft and .NET" value="true"

activePackageSource:
        add key="RETRACTED 1" value="A VALID V2 URL"
        add key="RETRACTED 2" value="ANOTHER VALID V2 URL"
```

7) Run this command `dotnet restore MyTest\MyTest.csproj`, the build logs dont report the warnings about the security flaw:

```
C:\MyTest\MyTest>dotnet restore
  Determining projects to restore...
  Restored C:\MyTest\MyTest\MyTest.csproj (in 414 ms).
```

To make this work, I have to remove nuget.org as a disabled package source. This is the output I get after removing nuget.org as a disabled package source from C:\MyTest\NuGet.config:

```
C:\MyTest\MyTest>dotnet restore
  Determining projects to restore...
C:\MyTest\MyTest\MyTest.csproj : **warning NU1903**: Package 'System.Formats.Asn1' 6.0.0 has a known high severity vulnerab
ility, https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-447r-wph3-92pm [C:\MyTest\MyTest\MyTest.sln]
  Restored C:\MyTest\MyTest\MyTest.csproj (in 521 ms).
```

Even if I remove 

```
<vulnerabilityDataSource>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
  </vulnerabilityDataSource>
``` 
completely from my NuGet,config, I still get the build warning about security flaw as long as I don't have nuget.org in the list of disabled package sources.





### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet nuget why shouldn't require project when there is only one in the current directory" (#13553) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

.NET 9 SDK daily preview

### Worked before?

no, new feature

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

When the current directory contains only a single project file, commands like `dotnet restore`, `dotnet build`, `dotnet add package`, `dotnet list package`, and so on, all use the project file implicitly.

`dotnet nuget why` not only doesn't implicitly use the project file, but outputs an error message twice

```console
> dotnet nuget why Azure.Identity
Required argument missing for command: 'why'.

Required argument missing for command: 'why'.

Description:
  Shows the dependency graph for a particular package for a given project or solution.

Usage:
  nuget why <PROJECT|SOLUTION> <PACKAGE> [options]

Arguments:
  <PROJECT|SOLUTION>  A path to a project, solution file, or directory.
  <PACKAGE>           The package name to lookup in the dependency graph.

Options:
  -f, --framework  The target framework(s) for which dependency graphs are shown.
  -?, -h, --help   Show help and usage information
```

Compare this to `dotnet add package -h` which has:

```console
Usage:
  dotnet add [<PROJECT>] package <PACKAGE_NAME> [options]

Arguments:
  <PROJECT>       The project file to operate on. If a file is not specified, the command will search the current directory for one. [default:
                  C:\src\myrepo\]
```


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

[severity:It's more difficult to complete my work] [regression] [worked-in:17.12 Preview 1]
It's great that Visual Studio tells me that it can't resolve a package, but there are no actions that can be taken and no report of where the transitive dependency comes from.

It would be great if when I clicked on the error in the error log in Visual Studio if it took me directly to the package that has the missing transitive dependency

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] The package versions are inconsistent in the “Project” node and the “Packages” node of the Solution Explorer window after updating the parent project package" (#13713) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.12.0.75

### Worked before?

It is not a regression since it reproes on both D16.11\34601.136 and D17.11\35208.52.

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Repro Steps:    

1. Create a solution with two C# Console App (.NET core) projects in VS, make the project graph structure: App1 (parent project) -> App2 (child project). 

2. Right-click the App2 in Solution Explorer and select ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’ menu item to open PM UI.  

3. Click “Browse” tab, search the package (e.g. “Newtnsoft.Json”), select version 13.0.1 in the “Version” drop-down box and click the ‘Install’ button on the right panel. 

4. Observe the “Projects” -> “App2” node under App1 in Solution Explorer window and the package “Newtnsoft.Json” version is 13.0.1. 

5. Right-click the App1 in Solution Explorer and select ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’ menu item to open PM UI.  

6. Click “Installed” tab and install the package “Newtonsoft.json” from the “Transitive Packages”. 

7. Select a different package version 13.0.2 in the “Version” dropdown list and click the “Update” button on the right panel.  

8. Observe “Projects” -> “App2” node under App1 and “Dependencies” -> “Packages” node under App2 in Solution Explorer window. 

#### Expected:    

The package version is consistent in the above node since it is the same project. 

#### Actual: 

The package version is inconsistent in the above node as below:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ee60ecf9-c649-4c08-ad30-fb93d49d52be)
#### Note:     

The repro rate is 100%. 

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "LockFileUtils.CreateLockFileTargetProject allocates a lot" (#13712) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
CreateLockFileTargetProject allocates a lot due to the fact that it assumes that projects can provide their own assets. 
While that may be true with project.json iterations, that's not really possible with PackageReference.
